q: What are the symptoms of low blood pressure?
a: Symptoms of low blood pressure include lightheadedness or dizziness, feeling sick, blurred vision, weakness, confusion, and fainting. These symptoms may indicate that your blood pressure is too low.

q: When should I see a GP for low blood pressure symptoms?
a: You should see a GP if you keep experiencing symptoms of low blood pressure, such as dizziness and fainting.

q: How can I check my blood pressure?
a: You can check your blood pressure by visiting a pharmacist, practice nurse, or GP, or you can monitor it at home using a home blood pressure monitor.

q: Where can I find more information about monitoring blood pressure at home?
a: You can find information on monitoring your blood pressure at home and choosing a monitor from Blood Pressure UK.

q: What should I do if I have a recent blood pressure reading?
a: If you have a recent blood pressure reading, you can use the NHS Check your blood pressure tool to understand what your reading means and get information about what to do next.

q: How often should I get my blood pressure checked?
a: If you're between 40 and 74 years old, you should have your blood pressure checked at least once every 5 years as part of the NHS Health Check.

q: What treatments are available for low blood pressure?
a: If a cause for your low blood pressure can be found, a GP may recommend changing medications, wearing support stockings, or treating the underlying cause. Medication to increase blood pressure is rarely needed.

q: How can I ease low blood pressure symptoms?
a: To ease low blood pressure symptoms, you can get up slowly from sitting to standing, take care when getting out of bed, eat small frequent meals, and increase your water intake. Avoid sitting or standing for long periods, sudden posture changes, and excessive alcohol consumption.

q: What are the possible causes of low blood pressure?
a: Low blood pressure can be caused by various factors, including being fit and healthy, genetic predisposition, aging, pregnancy, certain medical conditions, and certain medications.

q: What are the symptoms of low blood pressure?
a: Symptoms of low blood pressure include lightheadedness or dizziness, feeling sick, blurred vision, weakness, confusion, and fainting. In some cases, standing up or changing positions may worsen the symptoms, known as postural hypotension.

q: When should I see a GP for low blood pressure symptoms?
a: If you keep experiencing symptoms like dizziness and fainting due to low blood pressure, it is recommended to see a GP for further evaluation and advice.

q: How can I check my blood pressure?
a: You can check your blood pressure by asking a pharmacist, practice nurse, or GP to do it for you. Alternatively, you can monitor it at home using a home blood pressure monitor.

q: What does a blood pressure reading of less than 90/60mmHg indicate?
a: A blood pressure reading of less than 90/60mmHg indicates low blood pressure.

a: You can find information about monitoring your blood pressure at home and choosing a monitor from Blood Pressure UK.

a: If you have a recent blood pressure reading, you can use the NHS Check your blood pressure tool to better understand your reading and receive guidance on what to do next.

q: How often should I have my blood pressure checked?
a: If you're between 40 to 74 years old, it is recommended to have your blood pressure checked at least once every 5 years as part of the NHS Health Check.

q: What treatments are available for low blood pressure?
a: The treatment for low blood pressure depends on the underlying cause. A GP may recommend changes in medication, wearing support stockings, or addressing the specific cause to alleviate symptoms. Medicine to increase blood pressure is rarely needed.

q: What can I do to ease low blood pressure symptoms myself?
a: To ease low blood pressure symptoms, you can try getting up slowly from sitting or lying down, taking care when changing positions, eating small and frequent meals, and staying hydrated. It is important to avoid sitting or standing for long periods, sudden posture changes, and excessive alcohol consumption.

a: Low blood pressure can have various causes, including being fit and healthy, inherited from parents, age-related, pregnancy, certain medical conditions (such as diabetes), and some medications.

a: The symptoms of low blood pressure include lightheadedness or dizziness, feeling sick, blurred vision, feeling weak, confusion, and fainting. If you experience these symptoms, it may mean that your blood pressure is too low.

a: If you're between 40 and 74 years old, you should have your blood pressure checked at least once every 5 years as part of the NHS Health Check.

Avoid sitting or standing for long periods, sudden changes in posture, and excessive alcohol consumption.
